conversation.content: [very sincerely] I've been tracking my carbon footprint for three months and it's... it's way worse than I thought.
Oh, hey, first of all—good on you for actually looking at it. Most people never even get that far, you know? What part surprised you the most?
[very sad] The flying. Just two trips to see my parents and I basically destroyed any progress from going vegetarian.
Mmm, yeah, aviation is brutal. But listen, you're not destroying anything—you're learning what actually matters in your specific situation, which is, um, incredibly valuable information to have.
But everyone says individual actions don't matter anyway, that it's all corporations.
[long pause] So that's... that's partly true but also kind of a cop-out? Like yes, corporations produce most emissions, but they're producing stuff for us, right? Your choices do ripple outward.
How do you not just feel hopeless about it?
Honestly? Some days I do feel hopeless. But then I remember that, uh, perfectionism is just another form of giving up. Progress beats paralysis every single time.
What's your footprint like?
[monotone] About four tons annually, down from twelve. Took me three years. Mostly stopped flying, switched to renewable energy, eat meat maybe once a week.
Once a week? I thought you had to go full vegan.
[sarcastic] Oh sure, because making sustainable living feel like punishment is definitely how we'll get everyone on board. Look, reduction matters more than elimination for most things.
But isn't that just making excuses?
I mean, maybe? But beating yourself up helps literally nobody. You're already doing more than ninety percent of people by actually measuring and, um, trying to improve.
[empathetically] I know you're trying to make me feel better, but the numbers are just so overwhelming.
The numbers are overwhelming, absolutely. But here's what I've learned—you can't optimize everything at once. Pick one or two high-impact changes and actually stick with them.
Like what? What should I focus on?
[very meekly] Well, um, since flying is your big one... maybe start there? Could you do one trip instead of two? Or take a train? I know it's hard with family.
The train takes eighteen hours. That's insane.
It is pretty long, yeah. But, uh, you could work, read, sleep... and honestly? That eighteen hours might feel better than the guilt you're carrying right now.
